author: R Vimal Kumar
text:
Farmers from six panchayats near Dharapuram have expressed concern over the common bio-medical waste treatment facility coming up at Suryanallor stating that if the unit, when becomes operational, could cause health hazards and pollution.

The agrarian community had threatened to go on agitation if the district administration did not stop the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board from giving consent to operate the unit.

“We have now given a petition to Collector S. Jayandhi highlighting the factors that can pose threat to the health of people in the surrounding areas and also threat the ash disposal from the unit into earth can cause to agriculture.

Earlier petitions given to the officials at the revenue divisional level did not evoke any interventions and hence, gave to the Collector,”, S. R. Velusamy, vice-president of the Movement formed by the people against the setting up of the facility, told The Hindu.

Consent

When contacted TNPCB officials said that the unit, promoted by a group of doctors to treat the bio-medical wastes generated in the district at the rate of 2.5 tonnes per day, was given only the consent to establish after it had been assured that there was no habitation situated within a kilometre radius of the facility.

“The consent to operate will be given only when it was confirmed that all pollution control norms been complied with”, said the officials.

They added that all human parts wastes would be sent to insinuator and the resultant ash produced, which is extremely negligible, would be sent to a State-recognised facility in Thiruvallur district not buried in the earth as alleged by the farmers.
title: Farmers threaten agitation against bio-medical waste treatment facility
